messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Efficient Algorithms for Semirandom Planted CSPs at the Refutation Threshold

Paper Abstract: Abstract We present an efficient algorithm to solve semirandom planted instances of any Boolean constraint satisfaction problem (CSP). The semirandom model is a hybrid between worst-case and average-case input models, where the input is generated by (1) choosing an arbitrary planted assignment x‚àósuperscriptùë•x^{*}, (2) choosing an arbitrary clause structure, and (3) choosing literal negations for each clause from an arbitrary distribution ‚Äúshifted by x‚àósuperscriptùë•x^{*}‚Äù so that x‚àósuperscriptùë•x^{*} satisfies each constraint. For an nùëõn-variable semirandom planted instance of a kùëòk-arity CSP, our algorithm runs in polynomial time and outputs an assignment that satisfies all but a o‚Äã(1)ùëú1o(1)-fraction of constraints, provided that the instance has at least O~‚Äã(nk/2)~ùëÇsuperscriptùëõùëò2\tilde{O}(n^{k/2}) constraints. This matches, up to polylog‚Äã(n)polylogùëõ\mathrm{polylog}(n) factors, the clause threshold for algorithms that solve fully random planted CSPs [FPV15], as well as algorithms that refute random and semirandom CSPs [AOW15, AGK21]. Our result shows that despite having worst-case clause structure, the randomness in the literal patterns makes semirandom planted CSPs significantly easier than worst-case, where analogous results require O‚Äã(nk)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõùëòO(n^{k}) constraints [AKK95, FLP16]. Perhaps surprisingly, our algorithm follows a significantly different conceptual framework when compared to the recent resolution of semirandom CSP refutation. This turns out to be inherent and, at a technical level, can be attributed to the need for relative spectral approximation of certain random matrices ‚Äî reminiscent of the classical spectral sparsification ‚Äî which ensures that an SDP can certify the uniqueness of the planted assignment. In contrast, in the refutation setting, it suffices to obtain a weaker guarantee of absolute upper bounds on the spectral norm of related matrices. Keywords: Semirandom CSPs, Expander Decomposition, Spectral Sparsification

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The phase transition in 1-in-k SAT and NAE 3-SAT",
        "Better approximation algorithms for Set splitting and Not-All-Equal SAT",
        "Strongly refuting all semi-random Boolean CSPs",
        "Polynomial time approximation schemes for dense instances of NP-hard problems",
        "How to Refute a Random CSP",
        "Cryptographic Hardness of Random Local Functions: Survey",
        "Detection in the stochastic block model with multiple clusters: proof of the achievability conjectures, acyclic bp, and the information-computation gap",
        "Sum of Squares Lower Bounds from Pairwise Independence",
        "Efficient probabilistically checkable proofs and applications to approximations",
        "SDP gaps from pairwise independence",
        "Hiding solutions in random satisfiability problems: A statistical mechanics approach",
        "Algorithms approaching the threshold for semi-random planted clique",
        "Noisy Tensor Completion via the Sum-of-Squares Hierarchy",
        "On the security of Goldreich‚Äôs one-way function",
        "Coloring Random and Semi-Random k-Colorable Graphs",
        "Sum-of-squares proofs and the quest toward optimal algorithms",
        "An efficient sparse regularity concept",
        "Strong refutation heuristics for random kùëòk-SAT",
        "Satisfiability threshold for random regular NAE-SAT",
        "Relations between average case complexity and approximation complexity",
        "Refuting Smoothed 3CNF Formulas",
        "Heuristics for semirandom graph problems",
        "Semialgebraic Proofs and Efficient Algorithm Design",
        "Sub-exponential Approximation Schemes for CSPs: From Dense to Almost Sparse",
        "Subsampled Power Iteration: a Unified Algorithm for Block Models and Planted CSP‚Äôs",
        "On the Complexity of Random Satisfiability Problems with Planted Solutions",
        "Algorithms and certificates for Boolean CSP refutation: smoothed is no harder than random",
        "Recognizing more random unsatisfiable 3-sat instances efficiently",
        "Candidate One-Way Functions Based on Expander Graphs",
        "Some optimal inapproximability results",
        "A simple and sharper proof of the hypergraph Moore bound",
        "On the Complexity of k-SAT",
        "Generating Hard Satisfiable Formulas by Hiding Solutions Deceptively",
        "Random sampling in cut, flow, and network design problems",
        "Sum of squares lower bounds for refuting any CSP",
        "Reweighted Belief Propagation and Quiet Planting for Random k-SAT",
        "On clusterings: Good, bad and spectral",
        "Hiding Quiet Solutions in Random Constraint Satisfaction Problems",
        "The Projection Games Conjecture and the NP-Hardness of ln‚Å°nùëõ\\ln n-Approximating Set-Cover",
        "Two-query PCP with subconstant error",
        "On ŒµùúÄ\\varepsilon-biased generators in NC0",
        "Lower Bounds for CSP Refutation by SDP Hierarchies",
        "Goldreich‚Äôs PRG: evidence for near-optimal polynomial stretch",
        "Exact tensor completion with sum-of-squares",
        "Strongly refuting random CSPs below the spectral threshold",
        "Spectral sparsification of graphs",
        "Expander decomposition and pruning: Faster, stronger, and simpler",
        "An introduction to matrix concentration inequalities",
        "The Kikuchi Hierarchy and Tensor PCA",
        "Fully-dynamic minimum spanning forest with improved worst-case update time"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Efficient Algorithms for Semirandom Planted CSPs at the Refutation Threshold, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
